availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). titleStmt.title: Specimen epigrammatum Iacobo Primo Britanniarum Regi dicatum a G. Cragio I.D.
titleStmt.author: Craig, George, fl. 1624.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2010-01 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2010-04 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: Specimen EPIGRAMMATVM IACOBO PRIMO Britanniarum Regi
Dicatum A G. CRAGIO I. D.

div.l: PErſa ſuo Regi pauper de flumine munus
Hauſit, & acceptum Rex venerande fuit.
Euphratis dedit hic, ego do Permeſſidis hauſtum,
Et de pierio pocula fonte tibi.
Si capis, & gratum eſt: rotum Permeſſida ducam,
Et Tameſis ſacra turgidus ibit aqua.

div.head: II.
div.l: SAcrorum genibus Regum rudis illa vetuſtas
Et dextris folita eſt baſia ferre Deûm.
Nos quite merito veneramur maxime Regum
Dignamur dextrae baſia ferre tuae.
Nempe Deû ſocia qui protegis omnia dextra;
Non alia melius parte colendus eras.

div.head: III.
div.l: RElligio tecum Scotorum in finibus orta,
Et tecum in cunis paene repoſta fuit.
Nec tantum nata eſt, ſed tecum crevit & aucta eſt,
Et viſa eſt nobis paene gemella tibi.

Vt
que puer quondam, nunc vir perfectus haberis,
Sic per te culmen nuper adepta ſuum eſt.
Ergo Relligio tantum nunc diſtat ab illa,
Quantum à te diſtas maxime vir puero.

div.head: IV.
div.l:
ASſiſtit jus faſ
que Iovi (ſi credere fas eſt)
Vt juſtum ſit quod Rex ſine lege velit.

Aſſiſtit jus faſ
que tibi digniſſime Regum
Vt quicquid juſtum eſt hoc ſine fine velis.

Fallor, & id fas eſt de te quo
que credere, quando
Quae ſunt juſta velis, nec niſi juſta velis.

div.head: V.
div.l: CVm ſpecies Rex magne feris Natura miniſtret

Queis hoſtem valeat noſcere quae
que ſuum:
Cur qua te noſcant nullam Natura miniſtrat▪

Qui tot venando ſternis ubi
que feras?
Nempe feras à te tutari neſcia noto,
Te non praenotum maluit eſſe malum.

div.head: VI.
div.l: CVm ferus ad pugnam toties te concitet hoſtis,
Ludere cur tantum Rex Iäcobe ſoles?
Nempe datur cuivis pugnando vincere poſſe,
Hoſtes ludendo vincere poſſe tibi.

div.head: VII.
div.l: CVr Chriſtus Domini ſperanti plurima nil das,
At Chriſtus Dominus ſpes jubet eſſe ratas?

Caſus ubi
que valet: patrius ſibi caſus habendi eſt,
Conveniens votis eſt minus ille meis.
Sit Ieſu rectus, quia non ens nominat ut ſit,
Communem patrium fecit utrique Dens.
Vt mihi des quae ſunt, proprium tibi reddo dativū,
Nec Chriſtum Domini te voco, ſed Domino.
AVguſto ſub Patre geris res Carole noſtras,

Auſpiciiſ
que Patris commoda noſtra juvas.
Et quae te quondam ſenſura Britannia Regem eſt,
Nunc conſultorem ſentit adeſſe ſibi.
Ergo dedit multis regnum natura, mererc
Regnum ſed ſoli contigit ante tibi.

div.head: II
div.l: PRincipis exemplar digni ſi Carole quaeris,

Quod
que olim fugias, quod
que ſequaris, aves.
Non ego Zenonem jubeam vel adire Platonem,

Et vetus et mancum eſt quicquid uter
que docet.
Nec jubeam Iuſti quamvis pia dogmata Lipſi,
Vel Machiavelli ſcripta nefanda legas.
Omnis ad exemplar formetur vita paternum,
Tu regere imperio non meliore potes.

div.head: Ad Ponticum.
div.l: SEptimus innumeris cū nummis labitur annus,
Dum quaeris Domino complacuiſſe tuo.
Octavuſque fugit, dum quaeris quod tibi quaeras;
Nonus dum quaeris Regis habere manum.
Poſtremò remoras dum quaeris tollere cunctas,
Fecerunt vacuum te tria luſtra ſenem.
Hei mihi, quaerendo tempus conſumis & aera:
Vis fieri dives, Pontice? quaere nihil.

div.head: Ad Paulum.
div.l: INter quaeſtores unus mihi Paule videris▪
Fidus, et officio dignior eſſe tuo.
Non tamen hoc dubio didici ſermone popelli,
Difficile eſt veſtram teſte probare fidem.
Quam reliquos probat eſſe malos opulentia dives,
Tam tua paupertas te probat eſſe probum.

div.head: In Gillonem.
div.l: DEfunctae uxoris Gillo formavit in aere
Effigiem, multa quam pietate colit.
Et quoties ſpectat, toties amplectitur ulnis,

Oſcula
que adjungit, blanditiaſ
que facit.
Mira viri pietas! Vxoris Gillo maligna:
Relliquias gaudet ſaepe videre ſuae.

div.head: Ad G. Buchaenanum.
div.l: SInt verſus Buchanane tui vel Apolline digni,
Fas tamen eſt unum diſplicuiſſe mihi.
Nam dolet extremo tandem conſiſtere verſu,
Extremus verſus quod foret ille tibi.

div.head: In Iul. Scaligerum.
div.l: SCaliger obſcura depingens arte poëtam
Iudicio ingenium ſubjicit omne ſuo.
Scaliger obſcura ſe praeſtans arte poëtam,
Iudicium ingenio ſuſtulit omne ſuo.

div.head: Ad G. Egliſhemium.
div.l: QVod tibi cum patrio eſt Egliſhemi vate duellū
Aſpexi magna non ſine laude tua.
Et quamvis multi Buchananum vincere credant,
Tu ſolus palmam me tribuente feres.
Sciliet in quarto patriae das cantica ſolus,
Queis videor melius tergere poſſe nates.

div.head: Ad Damianum.
div.l: VXorem affectu tractas Damiane paterno,
ſed vix aſpectum ſuſtinet illa tuum.
Crede mihi neſcis juvenem tractare maritam,
Te cupit eſſe virum, non cupit eſſe patrem.

div.head: Ad Naevolum.
div.l: ARtibus ingenuis metuis committere natos
Naevole, quod multos infatuare ſolent.
Sed fruſtra metuis; fatuos de ſemine patris
Ars iterum fatuos reddere nulla poteſt.

div.head: Ad Avitum.
div.l: SAEpe doles miſerè tranſactae damna juventae,
Et velles primos poſſe redire dies.

Condoleo, vitulum
que tibi mactabo bidentem,
Stultitia ſapiens factus Avite tua es.

div.head: Ad Laeliam.
div.l: CVrſemper laudas, imitaris Laelia nunquam
Alceſtae factum? L. Res quia rara fuit.
Si faceres non rara foret: veram adjice cauſam,
An proſe vivit vir tuus ipſe ſatis?

div.head: Ad Geddaeum.
div.l: LIndeſi tibi mitto libens Geddaee libellum,
Quem volui eſſe meum, Neutonus eſſe tuum.

Vicit amorſocii ne dicito, nam
que ego cum ſis
Alter, dico meum, quod vocat ille tuum.

div.head: Ejuſdem Epitaphium.
div.l:
QVid Lacheſin duraſ
que querar Geddaee ſorores
Ante tuum longè te rapuiſſe diem.
Crede mihi non te ſolum rapuere ſorores,
Sed dum te rapiunt, me rapuere mihi.

div.head: In Broderium. I. C.
div.l: BRoderium noſtra cum ſors plantarit in urbe,
Vt prole & Latia lege beata foret.
Cur nos tam denſa foecundus prole beavit,
Sed nihilin latia lege beare valet?
Scilicet uxorem dederat quae gignere poſſet,
Nullam quae poſſet jura docere dedit.

div.head: Ad Turraeum.
div.l: VIrtutes Turraee tuas ructare volebat
Rufus, et ex alto mittere verba loco.
Sed velut AEſonidae cauſam dicturus ad urnam
Palluit, atque unum vix bene dixit ave.
Scilicet aptatis ſolum ad convitia buccis,
Non potuit titulos contemerare tuos.

div.head: Ad Pollinicum.
div.l: QVi tibi et uxori placeat Pollinice ſervum
Scribis in antiqua te reperiſſe domo.
Gratulor, et ſervi virtutes laudo, fed unum
Non placet, uxori quod placuiſſe refers.

div.head: Ad Paulum.
div.l: SAEpe bonam multis cauſam de millibus optas

Cur mare diverfis it
que redit
que vadis.
Conſule Cauſidicos et magnos Paule patronos,
Hi faciunt cauſam quamlibet eſſe bonam.

div.head: Ad Gallum.
div.l: DIceris obtuſas ſemper tractare machaeras
Vt valeas hoſtes ſternere Galle tuos.
Crede mihi fruſtra tantum te Galle fatigas,
Vt valeas hoſtes ſternere, ſis medicus.

div.head: Ad Fauſtinum.
div.l: VT vulgus Fauſtine fidem tibi praebeat, omnes
Fruſtra adhibes teſtes ad tua verba Deos.
Dic te mentiri, ſi vis tibi credere vulgum,
Nam verum hoc vulgus vel ſine teſte putat.

div.head: Ad Paulum.
div.l: QVod pro defunctis tantū ſibi Paule canendo

Lucrantur Monachi ſacrifici
que doles.
Sed fruſtra, nam ſi tantum ſibi Paule lucrantur,

Pro vivis Monachi ſacrifici
que canunt.

div.head: Ad Ponticum.
div.l:
VT vetulum multum
que ſenem te Pontice credam,
Enumeras canos, ut Melibaeus oves.
Crede mihi centum non credo Pontice canis,
Deliro capiti credere malo tuo.

div.head: Ad Album Paſtorem.
div.l: ALbe fidem ſolam media quid quaeris in aula?
Hîc ſpe, non ſola vivitur Albe fide.

div.head: Ad Avitum.
div.l: PLurima te nobis ſemper debere fateris:
Sat ſcio, nam ſemper ſolvis Avite nihil.

div.head: Ad Aulum.
div.l: COnſiliū cur ſperno cuum fruſtra Aule requiris:
Conſilium laudo, ſperno quod Aule tuū eſt.

div.head: Ad Quintium.
div.l: VXorem facientem aliquid ſibi Quintius optat,

Optatum obtinuit, cornificam
que tulit.

div.head: Ad Gallum.
div.l:
GEmmas at
que aurū multae jaculantur arenae,
Sola Dieppenſis Galle cacare poteſt.

div.head: In Plagiarium.
div.l: TAle tibi carmen qualis tibi contigit uxor,

Quae ne
que totatua eſt, quae ne
que tota mea eſt.

div.head: Ad Lectorem.
div.l: ARgutus tibi forſan erit meus ille libellus,
Cornutus forſan tu mihi lector eris.

div.head: Ad Zorlum.
div.l: QVodnihil inveniam ſine magno ſaepe labore,
Ingenium culpas Zoile ſaepe meum.

Sed fruſtra culpas: ſine magno nam
que labore
Stultitiam invenio Zoile ſaepe tuam.

div.head: Ad Ro: Aitonium Equitem.
div.l: NObilis Aitoni cui dictant carmina Muſae,
In ſacras veniet ſi liber iſte manus:
Nil tibi diſpliceat quod in illo plurima cernas
Vel mala, vel certè queis meliora velis.

Nam
que meum velle eſt ut poſſum ſcribere carmen,
Vt vis ſed carmen ſcribere poſſe tuum eſt.

div.head: Ad Aulum.
div.l: HIc breuis et curtus forſan liber Aule videtur,
Sed Regi ad longos non vacat Aule modos.
